quizzes.title: History Quiz: Man and Criminal
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, pair, rogue. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: On May 22, 1987, a multiple vortex tornado devastated this small Texas town.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Saragosa

questions.question: This man killed his first victim at the age of 12. By the time he was 15 he had become an expert shot. As he was almost 6 feet tall, strong and quick in shooting, people were afraid of him. However, the $1,300 reward made some ordinary citizens work out an elaborate plan to capture him.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cherokee Bill

questions.question: The towns of Dana, Enfield, Greenwich, and Prescott, Massachusetts were all disincorporated on April 28, 1938, because of the following.

options.text: It was agreed upon by a consensus of the 4 towns populace, to disincorporate due to flagging economic conditions.
All 4 towns were destroyed in a massive fire, and the area was rebuilt as a distant suburb of Boston.
The land was needed for a large reservoir.
A major railroad  company secured rights to the land and built a rail line through the heart of all 4 towns.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The land was needed for a large reservoir.

questions.question: This criminal was active during the Gold Rush. He was famous for leaving poems in the place of the gold that he had stolen. He never robbed valuables from the passengers of the stagecoaches, he preferred treasure boxes.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Black Bart

questions.question: In August of 2005, a Category 4  hurricane devastated the Gulf coast of the U.S.,  leaving much of the city of New Orleans flooded and without power.  Name the hurricane responsible for this widespread swath of destruction.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Katrina

questions.question: This famous outlaw was very friendly and most of his shooting was done in self defense. He became an outlaw after someone murdered his employer, Tunstall, whom he loved as a father. At Tunstalls funeral, this outlaw swore that he would kill every man who had been involved in the Tunstalls murder.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Billy the Kid

questions.question: His first crime was breaking into a store and taking a pair of pants, leaving a message that he would pay later.  He went on to steal cattle from farmers, and later robbed the San Miguel Valley Bank robbery in Telluride, escaping with $20,000.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Butch Cassidy

questions.question: Muscogee, Florida was once a thriving village located 20 miles NW of Pensacola, Florida.  It was founded in 1857, yet by 1928 it was all but abandoned.  What was the cause of this towns demise?

options.text: It was a haven for circus performers until 1925, when the circus left for Sarasota, and the performers followed.
It was a lumber mill town, and in 1928, the mills were sold.
It was a town largely dependent on the fishing industry, which experienced an economic downturn in the early 1920s.
It was flooded to make way for a canal which is part of the Inter - Coastal Waterway.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: It was a lumber mill town, and in 1928, the mills were sold.

questions.question: Although this criminal, who acted with his brother, would rob banks and trains, he was a favourite of the press of his day. In various journalistic materials he was often presented as the contemporary Robin Hood. It was a fact that he preferred to rob rich people, but it was simply because they had more money.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jesse James

questions.question: After his father was killed, this man sought revenge. He joined Quantrills fighting force. It was reported that he often frothed at his mouth in his almost psychopathic rage in battles. Some sources say he had a silk string with knots for every shot Yankee.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: William Bloody Bill Anderson

questions.question: Although he spent 32 years as a criminal, this Wild West rogue killed only a single person. He was mainly engaged in robbing banks and became the first criminal to use an automobile for his escape.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Henry Starr

questions.question: Jonestown, Guyana, home to the Peoples Temple religious cult,  was virtually wiped off the map in November of 1978, when the cult leader induced 900 of his followers to drink cyanide laced Kool - Aid.  What was this cult leaders name?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rev. Jim Jones

questions.question: While in charge of the guardhouse at San Carlos, this outlaw left his post to chase a man whom he considered responsible for his fathers death. When he came back, he argued with his superior and shot him in the leg. Arizona territorial legislature offered a $5,000 cash reward, but he was never captured.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Apache Kid

questions.question: This man was known as the Mexican Robin Hood. He set up a band of 5 members, all with the same first name. His band is credited with stealing more than $100,000 in gold and over 100 horses.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Joaquin Murietta

questions.question: This man was nicknamed the King of the Cowboys after he took part in the gun fight at the OK Corral in Tombstone, Arizona. When in 1879 he went West in Arizona, he achieved still more infamy, as the main antagonist of Wyatt Earp.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Johnny Ringo

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Town and Term
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, festival, burlington. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Sinepuxent, a town on the eastern shore of Maryland, was destroyed by a tornado in 1818, and never rebuilt.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Which American novelist, held Acid Tests in the 1960s, together with his circle of friends, known as the Merry Pranksters?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ken Kesey

questions.question: The term Summer of Love, associated with the hippie counterculture movement, refers to the summer of what year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1967

questions.question: Amy Carter, daughter of former president Jimmy Carter, was arrested in 1987 for protesting against campus CIA recruitment.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Which of these artists did not participate in the Woodstock festival, an event regarded as the high point of the hippie movement?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bob Dylan

questions.question: In this 1979 movie, Claude Bukowski, a boy from Oklahoma, visits New York City and befriends a group of hippies before being sent to an Army training camp.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hair

questions.question: In 1988, this talk show host once brought out 67 pound of animal fat to show how much weight they lost.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Oprah Winfrey

questions.question: Achilles, Kansas was a thriving town whose heyday ran from the 1870s to approximately 1915.   By the year 1930, it was all but defunct.  What was responsible for this towns demise?

options.text: It became one of the casualties of The Great Depression.
It was largely devastated by a tornado in late 1915, and never recovered economically.
It was bypassed by the railroad.
It was requisitioned by the U.S. Army Corp. of Engineers, and slated to be flooded  in 1930.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: It was bypassed by the railroad.

questions.question: This musician sang about an Uptown Girl in 1983.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Billy Joel

questions.question: What term did hippies use to refer to the institutions and structures they rejected?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Establishment

questions.question: Napoleon, Arkansas, a once thriving river town situated near the confluence of the Arkansas and Mississippi rivers, was flooded by the two rivers, but was successfully rebuilt.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: No

questions.question: This group is known for their 1984 song Were Not Gonna Take It.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Twisted Sister

questions.question: New Burlington, Ohio was once a community located in NW Clinton County, Ohio.  It was flooded when the U.S. Government  flooded Caesar Creek in order to construct a reservoir.  When did this take place?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1970s

questions.question: Mr. Rogers, from the childrens television show Mr. Rogers Neighborhood, once donated a sweater his mother made him to the Smithsonian National Museum of American History.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: The Free Speech Movement was a student protest that began in 1964 on the campus of which university?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: University of California, Berkeley

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: South Vietnam and North Vietnam
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, john, carolina. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This American was sentenced to life in prison, because in 1968 he led the My Lai massacre of Vietnamese civilians, including women, children and elderly men.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: William Calley

questions.question: Which British band released the hit single Hippy Hippy Shake in 1963?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Swinging Blue Jeans

questions.question: Name the route running from South Vietnam through Laos and Cambodia into North Vietnam, used by North Vietnamese for sending soldiers to the south and for supplying the NLF (National Liberation Front ).
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ho Chi Minh Trail

questions.question: Which of these 1960s famous hippie gatherings did not take place in San Francisco?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nambassa

questions.question: This Academy Award-winning film, directed by Oliver Stone, is based on the autobiographical book of Ron Kovic, a Vietnam War veteran, who became an anti-war activist.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Born on the 4th of July

questions.question: Which 1970 book includes advice on such topics as growing marijuana, starting a pirate radio station and stealing food?

options.text: The Cat Who Walks Through Walls

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Steal This Book

questions.question: The Vietnam War is viewed not just as a conflict between South Vietnam and North Vietnam, but as a conflict of ideology between the communist block and western values. Which of these countries did not belong to the coalition of forces that supported the western-oriented, South Vietnam?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The United Kingdom

questions.question: Shooting at anti-war demonstrators at this university on May 4, 1970, triggered a nationwide student strike across America.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kent State University

questions.question: This is the code name of the bombing operation in North Vietnam, carried out by the US armed forces, which lasted between 1965 and 1968.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Operation Rolling Thunder

questions.question: Two months after South Carolina seceded from the Union on December 21, 1860, Mississippi, Florida, Alabama, Georgia, and North Carolina voted to secede as well.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: In 1969, John Lennon and Yoko Ono held two, week-long Bed-Ins for Peace. In which city was their first Bed-In?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Amsterdam

questions.question: This US President introduced his policy of ‘vietnamization’- enabling the South Vietnamese to take more responsibility for fighting the war on their own.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Richard Nixon

questions.question: This American diplomat and statesman served as a National Security Advisor and later as a Secretary of State. He was awarded the 1973 Nobel Peace Prize for his role in negotiating a ceasefire and US withdrawal from the war in Vietnam.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Henry Kissinger

questions.question: In this film, set during the Vietnam war, the following words are delivered by Lieutenant Colonel Bill Kilgore:  You smell that? Do you smell that? Napalm, son. Nothing else in the world smells like that. I love the smell of napalm in the morning.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Apocalypse Now

questions.question: This communist offensive, launched on January 30, 1968, which comprised attacks on major cities and military bases throughout South Vietnam, was named after an important Vietnamese public holiday.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tet Offensive

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Battle and War
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, death, president. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What Union General in charge was defeated during the First Battle of Bull Run, the first major land battle of the American Civil War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: McDowell

questions.question: The Battle of Sandepu, the Battle of Mukden, and the Battle of Dairen are just three of the battles fought during this war.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Russo-Japanese War

questions.question: The Battle of Passchendaele, the Battle of Cer, and the Battle of the Frontiers were fought during this war.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: WWI

questions.question: The Battle of the Nile, the Battle of Radzyn, and the Battle of Aspern-Essling.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Napoleonic Wars

questions.question: Ulysses S. Grant and Robert E. Lee served together in which military conflict, regarded as a prelude to the American Civil War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mexican War

questions.question: Which general commanded the Confederate forces at the Battle of Gettysburg, that started on July 1, 1863?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Robert E. Lee

questions.question: What African American Regiment helped to assault Fort Wagner in South Carolina during the American Civil War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 54th Massachusetts

questions.question: The Battle of Grunwald, the Battle of Chojnice, and the Battle of Swiecin are three battles fought during this war.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thirteen Years War

questions.question: The Battle of Ludford Bridge, the First Battle of St Albans, and the Battle of Blore Heath are three battles fought during this war.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Wars of the Roses

questions.question: The Battle of Worcester, the Battle of Hopton Heath, and the Battle of Winceby are just three of the battles during this civil war.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: English Civil War

questions.question: After the death of this Confederate general on on May 10, 1863, General Lee remarked, I have lost my right arm.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jackson

questions.question: The Battle of El Alamein, the Battle of Narvik, and the Battle of Crete were fought during this war.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: WWII

questions.question: During the American Civil War, in April 1862, Union Flag Officer David Farragut, who was in command of the West Gulf Blockading Squadron, took control of which vital port of the South?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: New Orleans

questions.question: The Battle of Custoza, the Battle of Palestro, and the Battle of Calatafimi.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Italian Independence wars

questions.question: What play was President Lincoln watching at Fords Theatre, when he was assassinated by a Southern sympathizer from Maryland?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Our American Cousin

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Battle and Countries
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, bac, world. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This strategic meeting between the heads of the governments of the United Kingdom and the United States took place from December 22, 1941 to January 14, 1942.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Arcadia Conference

questions.question: Which of these events occurred on November  22, 1963?

options.text: The United States bombed North Vietnam for the first time
Robert F. Kennedy was assassinated in Los Angeles
John F. Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas
The Beatles performed first concert in the US

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John F. Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas

questions.question: Nazi Germanys attempt at invading the Soviet Union, known as Operation Barbarossa, started on what date?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 22 June, 1941

questions.question: In which month of 1940 did the Soviet Union occupy Latvia, Lithuania, and Estonia?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: June

questions.question: Which was the formal reason for the end of World War II, on September 2, 1945?

options.text: The number of civilians that had died
The usage of an increased number of atomic weapons

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The formal surrender of Japan

questions.question: What happened on July 14,1789?

options.text: Japan opened ports to international shipping
Argentina gained independence from Spanish rule
A mob of French peasants stormed the Bastille and started the French Revolution

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A mob of French peasants stormed the Bastille and started the French Revolution

questions.question: The Battle of Ap Bac, the Battle of Dak To, and the Battle of Hamburger Hill.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Vietnam War

questions.question: The allies of WW2 initially consisted of three countries, which were later joined by others. Which of these countries never joined the Allies?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Japan

questions.question: On 28 October 1940, launching the invasion from bases in Albania, Italy invaded this country.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Greece

questions.question: What historical event took place on October 14, 1066 AD?

options.text: The Chinese first used fireworks in battle
England was conquered by the Normans in the Battle of Hastings

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: England was conquered by the Normans in the Battle of Hastings

questions.question: What two countries were invaded by Germany on 9 April 1940?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Norway and Denmark

questions.question: The date November 11, 1918 is famous with what event?

options.text: The first case of Asian flu was reported in the USA

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: World War I ended

questions.question: The Battle of Uji, the Battle of Dan-no-ura, and the Battle of Muroyama were all fought during this war.

options.text: Wars of Sengoku Period in Japan

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Genpei War

questions.question: What happened on July 4, 1826?

options.text: Russia declared war on Turkey, starting the Crimean War
The Mexican army crossed into Texas
Both Thomas Jefferson and John Adams died

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Both Thomas Jefferson and John Adams died

questions.question: What historical event occurred on March 15, 44 BC?

options.text: Julius Caesar was assassinated by members of the Roman senate
The first calendar was started by the Mayans in Central America

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Julius Caesar was assassinated by members of the Roman senate

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Events and Nations
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, iraq, mining. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What major comic book character underwent a costume change in 1984, wearing a suit that was black and white instead of blue and red?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Spiderman

questions.question: Iran invaded Iraq in 1981.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: With what nations military did the US conduct desert exercises in 1981?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Egypt

questions.question: Which of these events took place on June 18, 1815?

options.text: The noble gas Neon was discovered
Russia claimed the territory of Alaska
Andrew Jackson and his troops defeated the British at New Orleans

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Napoleon was beaten at Waterloo

questions.question: Which of these landmarks could not be found on the Gettysburg battlefield?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hells Half Acre

questions.question: By 1983, less than 10% of all movie theaters in America had only one of these.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Screen

questions.question: Robert E. Lee commanded the Confederate army at Gettysburg. Who led the Union forces?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Meade

questions.question: President Reagan was shot in 1981 as he left this hotel.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Washington Hilton

questions.question: The date July 2, 1937 is remembered with what event?

options.text: Japan bombed Shanghai, off the coast of China, killing over 2,000
Amelia Earhart and her co-pilot disappeared flying across the Pacific Ocean

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Amelia Earhart and her co-pilot disappeared flying across the Pacific Ocean

questions.question: The US mining of what nations harbors created a congressional frenzy in April of 1984 and was  a case heard by the International Court of Justice?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nicaragua

questions.question: The US Federal Governments deficit in 1983 exceeded $250 billion?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: In what state was Claus von Bulow prosecuted?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rhode Island

questions.question: Which of the following events happened on March,1692?

options.text: An earthquake in Mexico killed over 10,000
The Salem witch trials began in New England
General Braddock was killed by the French
The Indians sold Manhattan Island to the Dutch

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Salem witch trials began in New England

questions.question: Which of these events occurred on December 29, 1170 AD?

options.text: Thomas Becket, Archbishop of Canterbury, was slain in his church
Mongols crossed the Danube river into Hungary
Danish ships landed at Greenland and claimed it as a province
Black Plague began in Genoa, Italy

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thomas Becket, Archbishop of Canterbury, was slain in his church

questions.question: The Battle of Gettysburg was fought on these dates.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: July 1-2-3, 1863
